CEREMONIES IMPRESSIVE
President Remsen Makes Important Annoncements on the Thirty-Sixth Annual Commemoration Day.

Amid all tlie gala bunting, gorgeous robes and impressive ceremonies usual to the occasion, the
thirty-sixth annual Commemoration
Day of the University was celebrated in McCoy Hall last Thursday morning. The orator of the
day was Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, full
of years and honors, a literary man
of note, a poet, a novelist and a
historian, and one of the foremost
Physicians of America. Among
the guests were the Governor of the
State, the Mayor of the city, and an
ex-Attorney-General of the United
States. An appropriate musical
Program was rendered under the
direction of Mr. E. L. Turnbull,
and included numbers played by a
string quartette consisting of members of the faculty of the Peabody
Conservatory.
After an opening andante by the
string quartette, Mr. J. K. Uhlig,
Mr. E. L. Turnbull, Mr. W. 0.
NVeyforth and Mr. T. deC. Ruth
sang a Latin benedicitus which was
Peculiarly impressive in the presnce of so many scholars robed
in the traditional uniform of their
.order. A prayer was then offered
by the chaplain of the day, Rev.
G. R. Grose, pastor of Grace
Methodist Episcopal Church, and
the president then introduced the
orator.
For more than an hour and a
half Dr. Mitchell, although in his
eighty-fourth year, held the unflagging attention of his audience.
.11is subject was: "George Washington," a theme peculiarly appropriate to the day upon which our
commemoration exercises fall and
one upon which the speaker is a
recognized authority. He reviewed
the various attempts of writers and
Painters to depict Washington's
character and endeavored to deduce
from these efforts a still more faithful likeness. He frequently caused
hearty laughter by humorous anecdotes and side-comment. The address was a model of light, entertaining and yet scholarly discourse.
After Dr. Mitchell had concluded and had received the honorary
degree of doctor of laws, Mr.
George Whitelock, in a few wellchosen words, presented to the
University a portrait of the late
Prof. Marshall Elliott as a tribute
from his friends. The president
then proceeded to his announceMents: George Victor Schick of
Fort Wayne, Ind., graduate student in Hebrew, Assyrian and
Greek ; Charles F. Meyer, assistant

ENTRIES IN GEORGETOWN GAMES
Eleven Hopkins Athletes Will Go to
Washington Saturday Night Hope
to Win the Point Trophy.

With hopes of winning the point
trophy in the annual Georgetown
indoor meet, a squad of eleven
track men, accompanied by Coach
Kocher and Manager Brown, will
leave next Saturday afternoon for
Washington, D. C. The games will
be held in Convention Hall as usual.
Captain Lee and Reeside will
represent Hopkins in the one mile
run. They are both veteran distance runners, and Lee, especially,
judging from his record-breaking
performance in the Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment Games, should stand excellent chance of breaking the tape
in the mile. Bacon, of City College, will make another attempt to
defeat Lee, but the Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment meet showed that Lee
need not worry about Bacon any
more.
Horrax is rapidly getting into
his old-time championship shape.
He cleared the bar at 5 feet IIT/2
inches in the Hopkins meet, which
is only one-quarter of an inch below his best height in -this event.
He will give Bob Eller, of Georgetown, a hard fight in the 50-yard
hurdles.
Liebensperger won the high
jump in the George Washington
meet two weeks ago. He will compete in this event Saturday night
and also in the pole-vault.
Tappan has been entered in the
high jump, pole-vault and 50-yard
hurdles. Johnny Morton will also
run in the 50-yard hurdles. Dignan, the big Californian, will represent the Black and Blue in the
shot-put. He has placed in both
the meets in which he has competed
this season, and may be counted on
to win or place on Saturday night,
provided the other contestants are
not given too liberal handicaps.
Catlin, who finished third in the
open half-mile two weeks ago, will
run in this event again. Uhler is
no longer a novice, as he placed in
the 600-yard run in the George
Washington games. He will seek
honors in the open 44o-yard run in
the Georgetown games. •
Hopkins will have two representatives in the novice events. They
are Todes and Snack. Todes will
run in the 50-yard dash (novice)
and also in the open event of the
same distance. Snack is scheduled
to compete in the 600-yard novice
and the half-mile run.
The engagement of Dr. Lloyd
P. Shippen. A. B. 'Or, M. D. '05,
to Miss Florence Brush • of this
city, has lately been announced.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 26, 1912
The Machine Towel.

After an experiment of several
months' duration, the University
authorities have come to the, conclusion that the penny-in the-slot
towel machines are not a success.
A statement is said to have come
from the treasurer's office to the effect that not enough money was
made on the towel machines to pay
expenses. This may be .a slight reflection on the cleanliness of the
students, but they are hardly to
blame. They could not reasonably
be expected to pay a cent every time
they wash their hands during the
course of a day. Therefore, although the machines were ostensibly installed as a sanitary measure,
they probably did more harm than
good, as many students, who formerly washed their hands while the
old roller towels were in operation,
must have neglected to d6 so 'since
the machines were in use, judging
from the fact that very few towels
were purchased. Last.week a large
roll of absorbent paper towels
was placed in the cage lavatory,
which may be used without charge.
They combine the .advantages of
being sanitary and also free. The
pemy - in - the - slot .machines will
probably be taken out.

United States and International
Arbitration." In previous numbers
of the same magazine, since the
University opened, he has published
"French Opinion of the American

Lords and Its •Outcome."

THE NEws-

1-41:1"rER for its recent editorial
urging a more adequate - commencement. Under the present-day circumstances at Hopkins the seniors
receive their degrees, shake hands
with each other and in such a conventional -way bring their college
days to a close. I am persuaded
that graduation exercises like this
are insufficient in themselves. What
we need in addition is something.
in which the class, as a class, takes
part: in other words, a class-day.
Then the departure would remain
treasured in memory, and the bonds
of fellowship between class members would be united more closely.
The one way a more adequate
commencement can be obtained is
through the senior class. It is
within the power of the present
senior class to confer on itself and
future generations of students a
great blessing-. Hopkins is waiting
for a strong senior class!
The cry of "Wait until we get to
lomewood" cannot serve in this
case. It is necessary, maybe, to
are
wait for 11(Anewood before we
able to have that college spirit
which collies only with dormitory
life ; but any class with initiative
could make use of . Homewood
Field for attractive class-day exercises. President Lee of 1912 ought
to arrange for definite action immediately. At some colleges, the senior class
gathers on the open field and has
the class poem read, the loving cup
passed, and similar festivities
carried out. I lornewood Field, with
its :surrounding- stands, also affords
an admirable place for an open-air
play. Possibly, too, on the evening of the class-day it 'might. be
feasible to have a moonlight excursion—"with the mandolin and
soft-voiced accompaniment.
Surely the senior class of 10'2
to such an occasion, and if
is
it will try to make its graduation ;i
Ill emorable one, it will doubtless
receive bulb the support and thank
of alumni and students.

It was a happy, though somewhat
weary (from chasing freshmen),
crowd that assembled in the Hotel
Emerson last Monday night. "The
virgins that bore us company," had
been induced by threats—persuasion
more or less forcible—to go quietly
to the banquet hall, so as not to precipitate a riot in the corridor of the
hotel. The agreement with the
"infantas" had been that they could
fight all they wanted to in the banquet hail; but so impressive was
the sight of the Class of 1914, as
a whole, that no traces of untoward
caprices were visible.
Copying the seniors, the University Ode was sung as a sort of grace
before sitting down. Some of the
1914 artists proceeded to decorate
the manly bosoms of their captives
with green jap-a-lac. The effect
when they were through would have
turned Rubens or Michael Angelo
green with envy—never did any
master paint any pictures half so
lifelike, so flesh-colored, so intensely
natural in the only real sense. Guy
Hollyday, the president of the
sophomores, was down for the first
toast "Us"—"come sophies bold
and cruel," but as he was sick in bed
Toastmaster Barton introduced Mr.
"Johnny" Yost, who read an admirable paper from Mr. Hollyday, and
"jestchulated" in the most approved
manner. For the next toast Mr.
Barton warmed up right and presented (one shouldn't say "introduced") Mr. John Dorsey in a most
lengthy and laudatory manner. Two
more toasts were given after this
by Mr. Sutton and Mr. Catlin.
Mr. Sutton's toast was "Greene
Goods" or "What's Home Without
Mother?" This was by far the
most amusing speech of the evening, although several of the fellows were seen to start nervously
(Conlinned on page 6, col. 2.)

They do say them bum Johns Hopkins professors is now tryin' to make
. the Legislature cough up a million
and
a half to build a college out at Homewood. More bunk. A person would
think we had enough colleges already,
but it seems like as soon as one is opened
tip, some gink goes to work and tries to
open up another one. This town is rotten with colleges. We got colleges to
teach doctorin , colleges to teach toothPullin', colleges to teach elocution, colleges to teach lavvyerin'. And what good
do they do? Not a darn bit. Nobody
don't never get nothing out of 'em.
They say this here new johns Hopkins college is to teach engineerin'
Something new again! In former times,
When. a young fellow wanted to learn
engineerin', he went to work and seen
the boss down at Mount Clare, and the
boss put him to work firm' a yard engine, and when he knowed how to shovel
coal 0. K. they put him on a' freight
engine, and then, in two or three years,
he was a fireman and getting good wages.
And after that all he had to do was tO
wait till they needed another engineer,
and when they needed one they give
him the job, and that was all there was
to it.
----But now, so they say, an engineer
,qught to go to college and study geology
and all that bug stuff, and brush his hair
straight back, and go bustin' aroun' in
One of them football suits, and play on a
niandoleen, and stand in a bunch with
lot of other young muts and holler
'Rah, rah, rah; ray, ray, ray; icky-acky,
leky-acky ; bing!” So it seems shovlin'
coal has went out of fashion. What they
, do now is to make a dude outen a young
fellow—and then give him a engine to
run. • God help the railroads!
Wait till you see the. teachers they hire
to learn the scholars. You would say
the sensible thing to do would be to go
to work and dig up a couple of engineers
who knOwed the business, and then back
an engine up on the siding and let the
engineers get into the cab and show the
scholars how to work the different
handles. But I bet you ten to one they
don't do nothing of the kind at the Johns
Hopkins.. No, sir. Them roosters does
things different.. What they will do is
to send out for a-bunch . of professors
With 0 lot. of .1). D's 'after their names
and sic 'eni on the scholars.. And all the
talk will be in Latin! Just, think of it!
Think of learnin a young fellow how
to fire a engine in Latin ! '

CEREMONIES IMPRESSIVE
President Remsen Makes Important Annoncements on the Thirty-Sixth Annual Commemoration Day.

Amid all tlie gala bunting, gorgeous robes and impressive ceremonies usual to the occasion, the
thirty-sixth annual Commemoration
Day of the University was celebrated in McCoy Hall last Thursday morning. The orator of the
day was Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, full
of years and honors, a literary man
of note, a poet, a novelist and a
historian, and one of the foremost
Physicians of America. Among
the guests were the Governor of the
State, the Mayor of the city, and an
ex-Attorney-General of the United
States. An appropriate musical
Program was rendered under the
direction of Mr. E. L. Turnbull,
and included numbers played by a
string quartette consisting of members of the faculty of the Peabody
Conservatory.
After an opening andante by the
string quartette, Mr. J. K. Uhlig,
Mr. E. L. Turnbull, Mr. W. 0.
NVeyforth and Mr. T. deC. Ruth
sang a Latin benedicitus which was
Peculiarly impressive in the presnce of so many scholars robed
in the traditional uniform of their
.order. A prayer was then offered
by the chaplain of the day, Rev.
G. R. Grose, pastor of Grace
Methodist Episcopal Church, and
the president then introduced the
orator.
For more than an hour and a
half Dr. Mitchell, although in his
eighty-fourth year, held the unflagging attention of his audience.
.11is subject was: "George Washington," a theme peculiarly appropriate to the day upon which our
commemoration exercises fall and
one upon which the speaker is a
recognized authority. He reviewed
the various attempts of writers and
Painters to depict Washington's
character and endeavored to deduce
from these efforts a still more faithful likeness. He frequently caused
hearty laughter by humorous anecdotes and side-comment. The address was a model of light, entertaining and yet scholarly discourse.
After Dr. Mitchell had concluded and had received the honorary
degree of doctor of laws, Mr.
George Whitelock, in a few wellchosen words, presented to the
University a portrait of the late
Prof. Marshall Elliott as a tribute
from his friends. The president
then proceeded to his announceMents: George Victor Schick of
Fort Wayne, Ind., graduate student in Hebrew, Assyrian and
Greek ; Charles F. Meyer, assistant

ENTRIES IN GEORGETOWN GAMES
Eleven Hopkins Athletes Will Go to
Washington Saturday Night Hope
to Win the Point Trophy.

With hopes of winning the point
trophy in the annual Georgetown
indoor meet, a squad of eleven
track men, accompanied by Coach
Kocher and Manager Brown, will
leave next Saturday afternoon for
Washington, D. C. The games will
be held in Convention Hall as usual.
Captain Lee and Reeside will
represent Hopkins in the one mile
run. They are both veteran distance runners, and Lee, especially,
judging from his record-breaking
performance in the Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment Games, should stand excellent chance of breaking the tape
in the mile. Bacon, of City College, will make another attempt to
defeat Lee, but the Hopkins-Fifth
Regiment meet showed that Lee
need not worry about Bacon any
more.
Horrax is rapidly getting into
his old-time championship shape.
He cleared the bar at 5 feet IIT/2
inches in the Hopkins meet, which
is only one-quarter of an inch below his best height in -this event.
He will give Bob Eller, of Georgetown, a hard fight in the 50-yard
hurdles.
Liebensperger won the high
jump in the George Washington
meet two weeks ago. He will compete in this event Saturday night
and also in the pole-vault.
Tappan has been entered in the
high jump, pole-vault and 50-yard
hurdles. Johnny Morton will also
run in the 50-yard hurdles. Dignan, the big Californian, will represent the Black and Blue in the
shot-put. He has placed in both
the meets in which he has competed
this season, and may be counted on
to win or place on Saturday night,
provided the other contestants are
not given too liberal handicaps.
Catlin, who finished third in the
open half-mile two weeks ago, will
run in this event again. Uhler is
no longer a novice, as he placed in
the 600-yard run in the George
Washington games. He will seek
honors in the open 44o-yard run in
the Georgetown games. •
Hopkins will have two representatives in the novice events. They
are Todes and Snack. Todes will
run in the 50-yard dash (novice)
and also in the open event of the
same distance. Snack is scheduled
to compete in the 600-yard novice
and the half-mile run.
The engagement of Dr. Lloyd
P. Shippen. A. B. 'Or, M. D. '05,
to Miss Florence Brush • of this
city, has lately been announced.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 26, 1912
The Machine Towel.

After an experiment of several
months' duration, the University
authorities have come to the, conclusion that the penny-in the-slot
towel machines are not a success.
A statement is said to have come
from the treasurer's office to the effect that not enough money was
made on the towel machines to pay
expenses. This may be .a slight reflection on the cleanliness of the
students, but they are hardly to
blame. They could not reasonably
be expected to pay a cent every time
they wash their hands during the
course of a day. Therefore, although the machines were ostensibly installed as a sanitary measure,
they probably did more harm than
good, as many students, who formerly washed their hands while the
old roller towels were in operation,
must have neglected to d6 so 'since
the machines were in use, judging
from the fact that very few towels
were purchased. Last.week a large
roll of absorbent paper towels
was placed in the cage lavatory,
which may be used without charge.
They combine the .advantages of
being sanitary and also free. The
pemy - in - the - slot .machines will
probably be taken out.
Lindsay Rogers published in the
last issue of Americana "The
United States and International
Arbitration." In previous numbers
of the same magazine, since the
University opened, he has published
"French Opinion of the American
Civil War" and "The War on the
Lords and Its •Outcome."
Dean Griffin told the senior class
on Saturday that there have often
been concerted absences from class
by students, but that never before
have so many professors been under
the weather at one time. Among

THE NEws-

1-41:1"rER for its recent editorial
urging a more adequate - commencement. Under the present-day circumstances at Hopkins the seniors
receive their degrees, shake hands
with each other and in such a conventional -way bring their college
days to a close. I am persuaded
that graduation exercises like this
are insufficient in themselves. What
we need in addition is something.
in which the class, as a class, takes
part: in other words, a class-day.
Then the departure would remain
treasured in memory, and the bonds
of fellowship between class members would be united more closely.
The one way a more adequate
commencement can be obtained is
through the senior class. It is
within the power of the present
senior class to confer on itself and
future generations of students a
great blessing-. Hopkins is waiting
for a strong senior class!
The cry of "Wait until we get to
lomewood" cannot serve in this
case. It is necessary, maybe, to
are
wait for 11(Anewood before we
able to have that college spirit
which collies only with dormitory
life ; but any class with initiative
could make use of . Homewood
Field for attractive class-day exercises. President Lee of 1912 ought
to arrange for definite action immediately. At some colleges, the senior class
gathers on the open field and has
the class poem read, the loving cup
passed, and similar festivities
carried out. I lornewood Field, with
its :surrounding- stands, also affords
an admirable place for an open-air
play. Possibly, too, on the evening of the class-day it 'might. be
feasible to have a moonlight excursion—"with the mandolin and
soft-voiced accompaniment.
Surely the senior class of 10'2
to such an occasion, and if
is
it will try to make its graduation ;i
Ill emorable one, it will doubtless
receive bulb the support and thank
of alumni and students.

It was a happy, though somewhat
weary (from chasing freshmen),
crowd that assembled in the Hotel
Emerson last Monday night. "The
virgins that bore us company," had
been induced by threats—persuasion
more or less forcible—to go quietly
to the banquet hall, so as not to precipitate a riot in the corridor of the
hotel. The agreement with the
"infantas" had been that they could
fight all they wanted to in the banquet hail; but so impressive was
the sight of the Class of 1914, as
a whole, that no traces of untoward
caprices were visible.
Copying the seniors, the University Ode was sung as a sort of grace
before sitting down. Some of the
1914 artists proceeded to decorate
the manly bosoms of their captives
with green jap-a-lac. The effect
when they were through would have
turned Rubens or Michael Angelo
green with envy—never did any
master paint any pictures half so
lifelike, so flesh-colored, so intensely
natural in the only real sense. Guy
Hollyday, the president of the
sophomores, was down for the first
toast "Us"—"come sophies bold
and cruel," but as he was sick in bed
Toastmaster Barton introduced Mr.
"Johnny" Yost, who read an admirable paper from Mr. Hollyday, and
"jestchulated" in the most approved
manner. For the next toast Mr.
Barton warmed up right and presented (one shouldn't say "introduced") Mr. John Dorsey in a most
lengthy and laudatory manner. Two
more toasts were given after this
by Mr. Sutton and Mr. Catlin.
Mr. Sutton's toast was "Greene
Goods" or "What's Home Without
Mother?" This was by far the
most amusing speech of the evening, although several of the fellows were seen to start nervously
(Conlinned on page 6, col. 2.)

The Free Lance Tilts at Hopkins—Mr.
H. L. Mencken of The Evening
Sun Discusses the J. H. U.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

THE NEws-LETTER takes pleasure
in reprinting our local Mr. Dooley's
animadversions for the benefit of
our alumni throughout the country:
H. L. Mencken,in the Evening Sun.

They do say them bum Johns Hopkins professors is now tryin' to make
. the Legislature cough up a million
and
a half to build a college out at Homewood. More bunk. A person would
think we had enough colleges already,
but it seems like as soon as one is opened
tip, some gink goes to work and tries to
open up another one. This town is rotten with colleges. We got colleges to
teach doctorin , colleges to teach toothPullin', colleges to teach elocution, colleges to teach lavvyerin'. And what good
do they do? Not a darn bit. Nobody
don't never get nothing out of 'em.
They say this here new johns Hopkins college is to teach engineerin'
Something new again! In former times,
When. a young fellow wanted to learn
engineerin', he went to work and seen
the boss down at Mount Clare, and the
boss put him to work firm' a yard engine, and when he knowed how to shovel
coal 0. K. they put him on a' freight
engine, and then, in two or three years,
he was a fireman and getting good wages.
And after that all he had to do was tO
wait till they needed another engineer,
and when they needed one they give
him the job, and that was all there was
to it.
----But now, so they say, an engineer
,qught to go to college and study geology
